entries.content: Use a permission-based opening on calls instead of meaningless pleasantries or launching into the pitch.
"Is this a bad time?" (Used as a permission-based opening).
"Would you like to hang up or let me have 30 seconds?" (Used as a permission-based opening).
"I know I'm an interruption. Can I have a minute to tell you why I called?" (Used as a permission-based opening).
Use anchoring at the beginning of a meeting to reduce pressure on the prospect and make them comfortable.
"If by the end of this meeting, you don't feel comfortable, that's perfectly okay." (Used for anchoring).
"If this is not a fit, I will be the first person to tell you." (Used for anchoring).
entries.notes: Positions you as an advisor, not just a seller.

entries.content: In sales conversations, focus on discovering the prospect's needs and challenges rather than immediately trying to sell your solution.
Ask many questions to understand the prospect's problems, goals, and challenges.
View objections not as personal rejections, but as questions or requests for more information.
Approach sales conversations with the mindset of helping the prospect, not just selling them something.
